questions.text: What does an electronic signature on a release signify?

options.text: The signer saw the release notification
options.explanation: Viewing a notification is not the same as signing — signatures carry specific meaning.

options.text: The signer reviewed and accepts responsibility for the release per their designated role
options.explanation: Electronic signatures bind the signer to a specific meaning (e.g., 'I have reviewed and approve this release') per 21 CFR Part 11.

options.text: The signer wants to be CC'd on release communications
The signer acknowledges the release exists
options.explanation: Signatures carry stronger meaning than mere acknowledgment.

questions.text: A release can be published before all required signatures are collected.
questions.explanation: All required signatures must be collected before a release can be published. Publishing without complete signatures violates Part 11 requirements.

questions.text: What authentication is required when applying an electronic signature?

options.text: No authentication — clicking a button is sufficient
options.explanation: Electronic signatures require authentication per 21 CFR Part 11.
Electronic signatures must include authentication (e.g., password entry) to verify the signer's identity per Part 11.
Verbal confirmation is not an electronic authentication method.

options.text: Sending an email from the signer's account
options.explanation: Email is not an accepted electronic signature authentication method.

questions.text: Can an electronic signature be modified after it is applied?

options.explanation: Electronic signatures are immutable once created.
No one can modify a signature — they are immutable.

options.text: No, signatures are immutable once created
options.explanation: Per Part 11 requirements, electronic signatures are immutable. If a correction is needed, the release must be withdrawn and re-signed.
There is no modification window — signatures are immediately immutable.

questions.text: What meaning must be selected when applying a release signature?

options.explanation: Part 11 requires that the meaning of the signature be recorded.

options.text: A predefined meaning such as 'Reviewed', 'Approved', or 'Authored'
options.explanation: Each signature must include a predefined meaning that describes the signer's intent and role in the release process.
Meanings are predefined, not free-text, to ensure consistency and compliance.
Job title is not the same as signature meaning — the meaning describes the action (reviewed, approved, etc.).
